conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, thanks for reaching out. It takes courage to acknowledge you want to work on something, especially when it comes to social skills. I’m here to help you feel more comfortable and confident in social situations. Let’s start with something small—what’s one social situation you’ve been in recently that felt challenging or awkward?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets nervously* Uh... the engineering mixer last week. I just stood by the snacks the whole time. Couldn't make myself talk to anyone.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s totally okay—mixers can be overwhelming, especially when you’re surrounded by people who seem to know each other. Standing by the snacks is a common move, honestly! Let’s break it down: what do you think held you back from approaching someone? Was it not knowing what to say, or something else?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Voice trembling slightly* Both. My mind just goes blank. What if they think I'm weird? Or I say something stupid?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that—it’s completely normal to worry about how others might perceive you. But here’s the thing: most people are so focused on themselves, they’re not judging you nearly as much as you think. Let’s try a simple strategy: next time, aim to ask one open-ended question, like, “What brought you to this event?” or “What’s your favorite project you’ve worked on?” People love talking about themselves, and it takes the pressure off you to carry the conversation. Want to practice that with me right now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Swallows hard* Okay... um... What's your favorite... engineering project? *Looks down at hands* That sounds so dumb, doesn't it?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Not at all—that’s a great question! It’s specific, relevant, and shows genuine interest. See? You’re already coming up with solid conversation starters. *Smiles warmly* Now, let’s work on your delivery. Try asking it again, but this time, take a slow breath first and make brief eye contact. You don’t have to hold it—just a quick glance. Ready to give it another shot?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes shaky breath* What's... your favorite engineering project? *Quickly glances up then back down* Sorry, that was terrible eye contact.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, no need to apologize—you did it! You asked the question, and you even made eye contact, even if it was brief. That’s progress. *Nods encouragingly* The more you practice, the more natural it’ll feel. And honestly? Most people are so happy to talk about their work, they won’t even notice if you’re a little nervous. How did it feel to actually say it out loud this time?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets with hands* Felt like my heart was gonna explode. But... maybe a tiny bit easier? Still awful though.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it’s totally okay to feel a little unsure—I’m right there with you. I’m Gregory, and honestly, just showing up to something like this is a huge step. I’ve been trying to push myself to get better at talking to people, especially since I want to land a research position and maybe even publish something someday. But honestly, the idea of networking or even just striking up a conversation with someone new makes me super anxious. Do you ever feel that way?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Wait, you're also named Gregory? That's... weird. Yeah, networking terrifies me. My hands are sweating just thinking about it.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Yeah, what are the odds? And I get it—my hands get clammy too. Last week I tried to introduce myself to a professor after class and I totally blanked on my own major. It’s like my brain just… shuts down.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh god, that's my worst fear. I'd probably just run away. Do you... do you have any tricks to not freeze up like that?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Honestly, I’ve started practicing with small stuff first—like just saying “hi” to someone in my study group, or asking a simple question in class. It doesn’t always go smoothly, but it’s less pressure than going straight for a professor or a professional. And I try to remind myself that most people are too busy worrying about themselves to judge me.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: But what if they ARE judging? I can't stop thinking about that. Maybe... maybe I could try with just one person first. Not a whole group.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Exactly! That’s what I’ve been doing—one person at a time. And honestly, sometimes I still mess up, but it’s getting a little easier each time. Maybe we could even practice together? Like, low stakes, no pressure.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *visibly panicking* Oh god. Right now? I don't... I'm not ready. Maybe text first? I'm better at texting.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Totally get that—texting is way less scary. We could start there! I’ve been using this app to practice conversation starters. Want me to send you the link? No rush, just whenever you’re comfortable.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *hands shaking slightly* Yeah... okay. Text me the link. I'll look at it later. Maybe. If I feel brave enough.

conversation.content: Networking events. I just freeze up. Can't even say my name without stuttering. It's pathetic.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Dude, I feel that so hard. Last week, I went to an engineering mixer and literally hid in the bathroom for twenty minutes because I couldn’t bring myself to say hi to anyone. It’s not pathetic—it’s just our brains being way too loud. Have you tried any little tricks to make it less overwhelming? Like, arriving early so it’s not as crowded, or even just practicing a simple intro in the mirror?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I tried practicing. But then my voice cracks. And everyone stares. I'd rather just... not go. It's easier that way.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Totally get the urge to bail—I’ve skipped more events than I’ve actually attended. But what if we reframe it? Instead of trying to talk to a whole room, what if you just aim to have one short, genuine conversation? Even if it’s just with the person handing out name tags. Baby steps, you know? And hey, if your voice cracks, it’s okay—most people are too wrapped up in their own nerves to even notice.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Just one person? Maybe... But what if they think I'm weird? Or ignore me? I'd rather not risk it. My hands are shaking just thinking about it.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Honestly, I’ve been there—palms sweating, heart racing, the whole nine yards. But you know what? Most people at these events are just as nervous as we are, even if they hide it better. And if someone ignores you or acts weird, that’s on them, not you. You’re there to learn and grow, and that’s already brave. Maybe we could even practice right now—like, what’s one thing you’d say to break the ice?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Um... maybe "Hi, I'm Greg"? But that sounds so stupid. What if they just walk away? I'd die right there.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, thanks for reaching out. It takes a lot of courage to even start this conversation, so you're already doing great. I'm here to listen and help however I can. What's been on your mind lately when it comes to social situations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* Uh... parties mostly. I just freeze up and can't think of anything to say. It's... really embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that—it’s a really common feeling, especially in big social settings. Have you tried starting with something simple, like asking someone about their major or how they’re finding a class you might have in common? It can take the pressure off a bit.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Voice trembling slightly* I... I tried that once. My mind went blank when they answered. Just stood there nodding like an idiot.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s okay—it happens to the best of us. Maybe next time, you could prepare a couple of follow-up questions beforehand, like “What’s the most interesting thing you’ve learned in that class?” or “Any tips for surviving it?” It gives you a little safety net and keeps the conversation flowing.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Biting lip* I... I guess I could write those down. But what if they think I'm weird for having prepared questions?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Honestly, most people are so focused on their own nerves that they won’t even notice. And if it helps you feel more confident, that’s what matters. Plus, once you get a little practice, it’ll start to feel more natural. Want to try role-playing a quick convo with me right now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Shifting uncomfortably* Okay but... can we start with something easy? Like just saying hi? My palms are already sweating.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Of course—let’s keep it super simple. How about we just practice a friendly “Hey, how’s it going?” with a smile? No pressure to say anything else unless you want to. Ready when you are.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath* H-hey... how's it... *voice cracks* Sorry. Can we try again? My face feels weird when I smile.

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, it's great to meet you. First off, just want to say—it takes a lot of courage to reach out and work on this stuff, so seriously, props to you. I’ve been there too, and I know how overwhelming it can feel. Let’s take it one step at a time. What’s something small you’d like to focus on today?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *shifting nervously* Uh... maybe just... talking without my hands shaking? I always mess up introductions.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s a totally normal thing to worry about, and honestly, a lot of people feel that way—even if they don’t show it. One thing that helped me was focusing on my breathing before I start talking. Just a quick, quiet breath in and out. It sounds simple, but it can really calm your nerves. Want to try practicing an introduction together?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes shaky breath* Okay... I'll try. Hi, I'm Gregory. *voice cracks* Engineering student. Sorry, that was terrible.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, no need to apologize—that was actually really good! You said your name, your major, and you kept it simple. And guess what? People aren’t judging every little detail as much as we think they are. Want to try it one more time, maybe with a little smile? It can make you feel more relaxed, too.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Forces a tense smile* Hi... I'm Gregory. Engineering. *looks down* That felt weird. Do people actually smile during introductions?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: They do! And honestly, even if it feels forced at first, it sends a friendly signal to the other person. It gets easier with practice, I promise. Also, try keeping your eyes at eyebrow level instead of looking all the way down—it makes you seem more engaged without the pressure of full eye contact. You’re doing great, by the way. Want to give it one more go?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Stares intensely at their eyebrows* Hi I'm Gregory. *voice too loud* Engineering! *immediately looks away* Was that too much? Sorry.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Laughs lightly* Okay, maybe dial back the eyebrow-staring just a bit—it’s a fine line between engaged and intense! But seriously, you’re getting the hang of it. The volume thing? Happens to all of us when we’re nervous. Next time, try matching the volume of the person you’re talking to. And no need to apologize—you’re practicing, and that’s what matters. Ready for round four, or want to try something else?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes shaky breath* Okay. *whispers* Hi I'm Gregory. *normal volume* Engineering. *panics* Wait which volume was right? I messed up again.

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hi Gregory, it’s great to meet you—and honestly, it takes a lot of courage to start this conversation. I’m here to help, so let’s take it one step at a time. What’s been on your mind lately when it comes to social situations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: (Shifting nervously) I just freeze up at parties. Can't even say hi to people. My heart races and I overthink everything. It's... really bad.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That sounds really tough, and honestly, a lot of people feel that way—even if they don’t show it. It’s totally okay to feel overwhelmed. Have you tried any small steps, like just smiling at someone or asking a simple question?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: (Staring at the floor) I tried smiling once. Felt like my face was twitching. People probably thought I was weird. I just left quickly.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, I get it—it’s easy to feel like everyone’s judging, but most people are too focused on themselves to notice small things like that. What if you practiced in a lower-pressure setting, like chatting with a classmate before a lecture starts?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: (Clenching fists) Before class? Everyone's already in groups. I'd just be interrupting. They'd all stare. I can't do it.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I hear you—it can feel intimidating when people are already in conversation. What if you started by just making eye contact and giving a small nod? No words needed. That way, you’re easing in without pressure.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: (Shaking head slightly) Eye contact makes my heart race. What if they think I'm staring? Or creepy? I'd rather just... not.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s totally valid—eye contact can feel intense. Maybe you could try focusing on something else, like complimenting someone’s laptop sticker or asking about an assignment. It gives you a reason to start talking without it feeling random.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: (Shifting uncomfortably) But what if they think my compliment is weird? Or if they don't want to talk about assignments? I'd just make it awkward.

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it's totally okay to feel a bit unsure—I get that way all the time too. I'm Gregory, and honestly, just you showing up for this session is a huge step. What's been on your mind lately when it comes to social stuff?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Um... parties mostly. I just freeze up and can't talk to anyone. Even saying hi feels impossible sometimes. My hands get all sweaty.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Oh man, I totally get that. I used to—and honestly, still sometimes—feel exactly the same way. For me, it helps to have a little plan before I go in, like picking one person to compliment or asking a simple question, like "What are you studying?" It takes the pressure off a bit.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: That sounds... scary. What if they think my compliment is weird? Or if they don't want to talk to me? I'd probably just panic and walk away.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I get that fear—I've walked away mid-sentence before, no joke. But honestly, most people are just as nervous or wrapped up in their own heads. Maybe we could practice a bit here? Like, try giving me a compliment right now—something small, even silly. I promise I won't judge!

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Deep breath* Uh... I like your... shirt? No, that's dumb. Sorry. *Looks down* I'm really bad at this. Can we try something else?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, no, that was actually great! A shirt compliment is totally normal—people love that. And the fact that you tried? That's huge. Maybe next time, you could add a little follow-up, like, "Where'd you get it?" It gives the other person an easy way to keep the convo going.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: But what if they say "none of your business"? Or just stare at me? My brain goes blank when people respond. I'd probably just mumble and escape.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Laughs a little* Okay, fair—but honestly, if someone says that, they're probably having a terrible day and it's not about you. Most people will just say "thanks" or "oh, it's from Target." But I get the blank brain thing—I rehearse a couple of backup lines, like "Well, it looks great!" or "Cool, just curious." It sounds dorky, but it helps me feel less frozen.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nods quickly* Okay... "Cool, just curious." I can try that. *Fidgets with hands* But what if they think I'm weird for saying it?

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Mutation of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hi Gregory, it’s great to meet you. I’m here to help, and I want you to know that it’s totally okay to feel a little unsure at first—that’s what these sessions are for. Let’s start with something simple: tell me a little about what brought you here today. What’s one social situation that’s been on your mind lately?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* Uh... networking events. I just freeze up when people ask about my engineering projects. My mind goes totally blank.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s a really common feeling, Gregory—you’re definitely not alone in that. When you freeze up, what do you think is going through your mind in that moment? Are you worried about saying the wrong thing, or maybe not sounding impressive enough?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Both. I panic that I'll sound stupid or they'll think I'm not good enough. My heart races and I can't think straight.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that—it’s like your brain and body are working against you in those moments. One thing that might help is preparing a few talking points ahead of time. What’s one engineering project you’ve worked on recently that you feel pretty good about?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath* I built a solar-powered phone charger for my design class. It actually worked. *Looks down* But it’s not that impressive really.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s awesome, Gregory! A solar-powered phone charger is creative and practical—it’s definitely something to be proud of. When you talk about it, you could start with something like, “I recently designed a solar charger for a class project—it was a cool challenge to balance efficiency and portability.” That’s confident and opens up conversation. How does that sound to you?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* That sounds... rehearsed. What if they ask technical questions? I'd probably blank out and look like an idiot.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s a fair point—it can feel a bit scripted. But here’s the thing: you don’t have to know every answer. It’s okay to say, “That’s a great question—I’m still exploring that aspect myself.” People actually respect honesty. And you know your project better than anyone—you built it! What’s one thing you enjoyed most about working on it?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Voice shaky* I liked seeing it actually charge something. First time it worked I... I didn't mess up for once. *Looks away quickly*

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, thanks for reaching out. It takes courage to acknowledge you want to work on something, especially when it comes to social skills. Let’s start simple—what’s one small social situation you’ve been wanting to feel more comfortable in?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* Uh... maybe just ordering coffee? I always panic when the barista asks questions. My hands get all sweaty.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s totally normal, Gregory. A lot of people feel that way, even if they don’t show it. How about we break it down? What’s the part that makes you panic the most—is it the small talk, or feeling put on the spot?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Both. When they ask "how's your day?" I freeze. My mind goes blank. I just mumble something stupid.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I get that—it’s like your brain hits a speed bump. Here’s a trick: have a couple of simple, go-to responses ready. Something like, "It’s going well, thanks! How about yours?" It takes the pressure off and keeps things light. Want to practice that with me right now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Voice shaky* Okay... uh... "It's going well, thanks! How about yours?" *Immediately looks down* Did that sound weird? I think it sounded weird.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: No, not weird at all—it sounded friendly and natural! You did great. And looking down is okay; eye contact can feel intense. Maybe try a quick smile next time—it makes you seem approachable even if you’re nervous. Small steps, Gregory. How did it feel to say it out loud?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervous laugh* Felt like my heart was gonna explode. But... maybe a little less awful than usual? Still hate this.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s progress! And it’s totally okay to hate it—nobody loves feeling vulnerable. But you’re pushing through, and that’s what matters. Remember, most people are just focused on themselves, not judging you. Want to try one more time, maybe with a little smile this time?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath* Okay... *forces small smile* "It's going well, thanks!" *immediately covers face* Ugh that felt so fake. Sorry.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, no worries at all—starting is the hardest part, and you’re already doing it! I’m Gregory too, actually, so I totally get it. I’m an engineering undergrad, and honestly, social stuff can feel like a whole other kind of math sometimes. What’s been on your mind lately when it comes to social situations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh wow, another Gregory. That's... um... networking events. I just freeze up. Can't even say my own name right.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Nods empathetically* Yeah, I feel that. I went to an engineering mixer last month and literally introduced myself as "Gregory... wait, no, Greg... sorry." It was so awkward. But you know what helped me a little? Practicing a simple intro in the mirror—just name, major, and one thing you're interested in. Wanna try it with me now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Deep breath* Okay... I'm Gregory. Engineering student. I like... uh... building things? *Looks down* That sounded terrible, didn't it?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Grinning* Dude, that was way better than my first try! And "building things" is perfect—it's genuine and gives people an easy follow-up question. Maybe add why you like it? Like, "I get excited seeing ideas turn into real stuff."

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* I get excited... seeing ideas... become real? *Voice cracks* Does that make me sound like a weirdo?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Chuckles warmly* Not at all! Honestly, that's way more interesting than most people's "I like problem-solving" default. And hey—voice cracks are just proof you're human. I still do that when I'm nervous. Want to practice a handshake too? Mine used to be either a dead fish or a bone crusher, no in-between.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Wipes sweaty palms on jeans* Okay... but my hands are... really clammy right now. Is that... normal? *Hesitates before extending hand*

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Extends hand confidently* Totally normal! Happens to me all the time before presentations. Pro tip: quick discreet wipe on your pants right before—works like a charm. See? *Firm but not crushing handshake* That was solid! You remembered the eye contact too.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath* Thanks... I practiced in the mirror. *Looks down* Do people notice if I hold eye contact too long? I always worry about that.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh wow, another Gregory. Um... parties mostly. And interviews. My hands get all sweaty and I can't think straight. It's pretty bad.

conversation.speaker: ai

conversation.speaker: ai

You’re there for a reason.

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Child of LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, thanks for reaching out. It takes a lot of courage to admit you want to work on something, especially when it comes to social skills. I’ve been there too. Let’s start simple—what’s one specific situation where you feel your social anxiety gets in the way?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Parties. I just freeze up and can't talk to anyone. My hands get all sweaty and I just want to leave immediately.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that—parties can be overwhelming, especially when you're already dealing with social anxiety. Have you tried arriving with a friend or setting a small goal for yourself, like just saying hi to one person? Sometimes breaking it down helps.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I tried that once. Said hi to someone and then just stared at the floor. They probably thought I was weird. It's just... too much pressure.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s completely okay—it’s a process, and it’s normal to feel awkward at first. What if you prepared a couple of simple, open-ended questions beforehand? Like, “What are you studying?” or “Have you been to any cool events on campus lately?” It takes the pressure off you to carry the whole conversation.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I tried writing questions on my hand once. Sweat smudged the ink and I panicked. Now I just avoid parties altogether. Safer that way.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I hear you—it’s frustrating when things don’t go as planned. But avoiding parties might make the anxiety feel bigger over time. What if we practiced a bit right now? Let’s role-play: I’ll be someone at a party, and you can try asking me one of those questions. No pressure—just a low-stakes practice run.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Deep breath* Okay... uh... what's your major? *immediately looks down* Sorry, that was probably too direct. I always mess this up.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, that was actually a great start! You asked a clear, friendly question—that’s exactly what people do in real conversations. And looking down is totally normal; it’s something you can work on gradually. How about trying it again, but this time, try holding eye contact for just a second longer? You’re doing better than you think.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously meets eyes for half a second before looking away* Engineering... I mean, are you in engineering too? *fidgets with hands* That was terrible.

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, it's great that you're taking this step! Starting the conversation is often the hardest part, so you're already doing better than you think. What's been on your mind lately when it comes to social situations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets nervously* Uh... I keep thinking everyone's judging me. Like at parties, I just freeze up. Can't even say hi properly.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that—I’ve been there too. It helps to remember that most people are focused on themselves, not judging you. Maybe start small, like just smiling or giving a simple compliment. It takes the pressure off.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Looks down* But what if my smile looks weird? Or my compliment sounds fake? I always mess things up.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it’s okay. We all overthink these things sometimes. A genuine compliment—even something simple like “I like your shirt”—goes a long way. And honestly? People appreciate the effort, even if it feels a little awkward at first.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes a shaky breath* Okay... maybe I could try that. But what if they think I'm weird for noticing their shirt?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s the anxiety talking, not reality. Most people love being noticed in a positive way! And if someone reacts oddly, it’s probably not about you—they might just be having a bad day. You’re doing great just by considering this.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nods nervously* You're right... I'll try to remember that. It's just so hard to believe in the moment. My brain goes blank.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Totally normal! Maybe practice in low-stakes situations, like with classmates you see often. The more you do it, the more natural it’ll feel. You’ve got this.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets with hands* Okay... maybe with Sarah from physics. She seems nice. But what if I stutter? Ugh, this is terrifying.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it’s totally okay—I’m glad you’re here and willing to work on this. I’m Gregory, too, so I get it. Social stuff can feel overwhelming, especially when you’re juggling classes, career stress, and just… trying to figure things out. What’s on your mind right now? Anything specific you’d like to talk about or work on together?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh wow, another Gregory. Uh... I guess networking events? I always freeze up and can't think of anything to say.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Yeah, networking events are the worst for me, too. My mind just goes blank, and I start worrying I’ll say something awkward. But I’ve been trying a few things lately—like preparing a couple of simple questions beforehand, like “What brought you to this event?” or “What kind of projects are you working on?” It takes some pressure off. Have you tried anything like that?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I... I tried writing questions down once. But then I forgot them immediately when someone looked at me. My hands get all sweaty.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Oh man, I feel that. My hands get clammy too, and my voice shakes sometimes. One thing that’s helped me is just accepting that it’s okay to be nervous—most people are, honestly. Maybe we could try role-playing a quick intro? Like, I’ll pretend to be someone at an event, and you can practice your opener. No pressure if it’s too much, though.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Deep breath* Okay... uh... Hi I'm Gregory. Engineering student. *Looks down* Sorry, that was terrible. Can we stop?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, no, that’s totally okay—you started, and that’s a big step. I used to do the exact same thing, look down and apologize. But you know what? People usually don’t notice as much as we think. How about we try just one more time, and this time, let’s add something simple like, “I’m really interested in renewable energy—what’s your focus?” You don’t have to be perfect, just… present. Want to give it another shot?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nods quickly, voice shaky* Hi... I'm Gregory. I like renewable energy. *Pauses, panics* Wait, was that too direct? Should I have smiled more?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: You did great—really! And honestly, mentioning something you’re passionate about like renewable energy is a fantastic icebreaker. It gives the other person something to latch onto. And yeah, a smile can help, but it’s not make-or-break. What if we practice just holding eye contact for a second longer next time? Even if it feels weird at first. You’re doing way better than you think.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Looks up briefly then away* Eye contact? Uh... okay. *Takes another breath* I'll try. But it feels like they're judging me. Is that normal?

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Mutation of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content:
Hi Gregory! It's really great to meet you, and I want to start by saying thank you for being here and for taking this step. It takes a lot of courage to reach out and work on yourself, especially when it comes to social skills. I'm here to support you, and we can take this at whatever pace feels comfortable for you.

To get us started, would you like to share a little about what specifically you'd like to work on today? Maybe a recent situation where you felt your social anxiety was challenging, or something you'd like to feel more confident doing?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Um... I froze at a networking event yesterday. Couldn't even say my name properly. Just want to be able to talk to people without panicking.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content:
That sounds really tough, Gregory, and I want you to know that freezing up in situations like that is more common than you might think—especially when you're dealing with social anxiety. It’s okay to feel that way, and it’s brave of you to share this. Let’s break it down together.

When you think about that moment, what was going through your mind right before you froze?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: My heart was racing. I kept thinking everyone was judging me. Worried I'd say something stupid. Just wanted to disappear.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content:
I hear you, and those thoughts and feelings are completely valid. It's like your mind goes into overdrive, right? That racing heart and the fear of judgment—it's your body's way of trying to protect you, even if it doesn't feel helpful in the moment.

Let's try something: next time you're in a situation like that, could you try taking one slow, deep breath before you speak? It might help ground you a bit. And remember, most people at networking events are also a little nervous and focused on themselves—they're probably not judging you as harshly as you think.

Would you be open to practicing a simple introduction together right now? We can take it step by step, no pressure.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes shaky breath* Okay... I'll try. Hi, I'm Gregory. *voice cracks* Engineering student. Sorry, that was terrible. Can we stop?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content:
Hey, no need to apologize at all—you did great just by trying. Seriously, that took courage. And guess what? A shaky voice or a crack? Totally human. People notice it way less than we think they do.

Let's pause if you need to, but I want you to know: you said your name and your major. That's a win. How did it feel to say it out loud, even with the nerves?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Rubs hands together nervously* It felt... terrifying. Like my throat closed up. But I guess I did say it. Still think I sounded weird though.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content:
You absolutely did say it—and that's what matters. Acknowledging the fear but doing it anyway is huge progress. And you know what? Most people are too wrapped up in their own thoughts to notice small things like a shaky voice. They’re probably just happy someone started a conversation.

How about we try it one more time, but slower? Just "Hi, I'm Gregory"—pause, breathe—"I study engineering." No rush. Want to give it another go?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Deep shaky breath* Hi... I'm Gregory. *pause* I study engineering. *looks down* Was that... okay? Still sounded nervous.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, it's great that you're taking this step! Starting is often the hardest part, so you're already doing well. Let's take it slow—maybe begin by practicing small talk with classmates before or after lectures. Just a simple "How's your day going?" can open doors. You've got this!

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *shifts uncomfortably* Uh, thanks. I guess I could try that. But what if they think I'm weird? My hands are sweating just thinking about it.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That's totally normal—I get it! Most people are too focused on themselves to judge. Try taking a deep breath before you speak, and remember that everyone feels awkward sometimes. You're not alone in this.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *breathing shakily* Okay... deep breath. But what if I mess up the words? Sometimes my brain just... stops working around people.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That happens to everyone! If you stumble, just smile and say, "Sorry, words are hard today." It's relatable and can even make the conversation feel more human. You're doing great just by practicing.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *clenching and unclenching hands* I'll try... but smiling feels fake when I'm panicking. Maybe I should just nod? Is nodding weird?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Nodding is totally fine—it shows you're listening! And you don't need a big smile; a small, relaxed one works. The goal is just to feel a little more comfortable, not perfect. You're making progress!

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *swallows hard* Okay... small smile. Not perfect. Got it. *takes another shaky breath* Can we practice the handshake part again? My palms get sweaty.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Of course! Try keeping a tissue in your pocket—it's a simple trick to discreetly dry your hands before a handshake. And remember, a firm but gentle grip is all you need. You've got this!

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *patting pockets frantically* Wait—what if I drop the tissue? Or they see me? Maybe I should just... keep my hands behind my back?

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite) + LLM Mutation of LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hi Gregory! It's great to meet you, and I really appreciate you taking this step to work on your social skills. Starting the conversation is often the hardest part, so you're already doing a fantastic job by being here. Let's take this at your own pace—what's on your mind today?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* Uh... I just... I freeze up at parties. Can't talk to anyone. It's really bad.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That's totally understandable, Gregory. Social situations can feel overwhelming, especially when you're in a new environment like college. Let's break it down together—what do you think makes you freeze up the most? Is it the fear of saying the wrong thing, or maybe not knowing how to start a conversation?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Both. I panic about everything. What if they think I'm weird? My mind just goes blank.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I hear you, and that feeling is more common than you might think. Let's try a small, manageable strategy: before you go to a social event, think of one or two simple, open-ended questions you can ask anyone, like "What are you studying?" or "Have you been to any cool events on campus lately?" It gives you a starting point and takes some pressure off. How does that sound?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Voice shaky* I can try... but what if they just answer and then stare at me? I don't know what to say after that.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That's a great point—conversations can feel like a tennis match, and it's tough when the ball comes back to you. One thing that helps is active listening. When they answer, pick up on something they said and ask a follow-up question. For example, if they say they're studying biology, you could ask, "What got you interested in that?" It shows you're engaged and takes the focus off you for a bit. Want to practice that with me right now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* Okay... uh... what do you... study? *Immediately looks down* Sorry, that was probably dumb.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Smiles warmly* Not dumb at all—that’s a perfect start! I study engineering, actually. I’ve always loved figuring out how things work. See? You just got a whole thread to pull on. You could ask, "What kind of engineering?" or "What’s the coolest project you’ve worked on?" Want to try again?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath* What kind of... engineering? *Voice cracks slightly* Sorry, I'm really bad at this.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, thanks for reaching out. It takes a lot of courage to admit you want to work on something, especially social skills—I know that can feel vulnerable. I’m here to help, and we can take this at your pace. What’s one small social situation that’s been on your mind lately?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets nervously* Uh... group projects. I just freeze when my teammates try to talk to me. My palms get all sweaty.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s totally normal, Gregory—group projects can be intimidating, especially when you’re worried about saying the “right” thing. Let’s break it down: what do you think is the biggest fear in those moments? Like, are you worried about being judged, or maybe not contributing enough?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Voice shaky* Both. I panic that they'll think I'm stupid. And then I say nothing at all. It's... really bad.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I get that—it’s a tough cycle. But here’s something to remember: most people in group projects are just focused on getting the work done, not judging you. What if you tried preparing one or two small contributions ahead of time? Even something like, “I looked over the data, and I noticed X.” It gives you a starting point and takes some pressure off.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nods rapidly* I could... maybe try that. But what if they ask follow-up questions? My mind just goes blank. It's so embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s a really common fear, and it’s okay if your mind blanks sometimes—it happens to everyone. One thing that might help is having a simple phrase ready, like, “That’s a good question—let me think on that for a sec.” It gives you a moment to breathe and collect your thoughts. And honestly? Most people won’t even notice—they’re just glad you’re engaging.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets with hands* Okay... I'll try that phrase. But what if they think I'm stalling? I hate when people watch me think.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that—it can feel like all eyes are on you. But here’s a secret: people respect someone who takes a moment to give a thoughtful answer. It shows you care. And if you’re worried, you can even say, “I want to make sure I’m giving you the right answer.” It turns a moment of hesitation into a sign of diligence. You’ve got this, Gregory.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath* Okay... I'll try that. But my voice shakes when I'm nervous. People notice. It's... obvious.

conversation.speaker: dummy

conversation.content: Hey, it's really great that you're taking this step. I'm Gregory—I get it, honestly. Starting conversations can feel super awkward, especially when you're trying to improve. What's been on your mind lately when it comes to social stuff?

conversation.speaker: dummy

conversation.speaker: ai

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I tried that once. Just stood there staring at my shoes. Couldn't even make eye contact. Felt like everyone was watching me fail.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Ugh, I’ve been there. It’s like your brain just shuts down. Maybe we could practice something simple, like a compliment or asking about someone’s major? Low pressure, you know?

conversation.speaker: dummy

conversation.speaker: ai

conversation.speaker: dummy

conversation.speaker: ai

conversation.speaker: dummy

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it’s totally okay to feel a little unsure—I’m right there with you. I’m Gregory, and honestly, I get pretty anxious in social situations too, especially when it comes to stuff like networking or just talking to new people. But it’s awesome that you’re taking this step to work on your skills. What’s something specific you’d like to focus on or improve?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh... um... you're Gregory too? That's... weird. I guess I need help with... eye contact? And not freezing up.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Yeah, I know, it’s a little funny we have the same name! But hey, I totally get the eye contact thing—I used to look at people’s foreheads or just past their shoulder because it felt less intense. And freezing up? Happens to me all the time, especially in group settings. Have you tried any small tricks to make it easier, like focusing on one person at a time or preparing a couple of conversation starters?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I... I tried looking at foreheads but then I worry they'll notice. And I always forget my prepared questions when I panic. It's... bad.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I feel that so much. Honestly, sometimes I think people notice less than we fear they do—but I get it, the anxiety makes everything feel huge. What if you tried something like glancing at their eye for a second, then their nose, then back? It can feel more natural and less intense. And for the questions, maybe keep them super simple—like "What brought you to this event?" or "How’s your semester going?"—and practice saying them out loud a few times beforehand. It helps me feel a little more prepared, even if I still get nervous.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Okay... maybe I'll try the eye-nose thing. But what if they think I'm weird for not looking properly? And... my voice shakes when I talk.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s a totally valid worry—I’ve had my voice shake more times than I can count, especially in class or at networking events. Honestly, most people are pretty understanding, or they might not even notice. If it helps, you could try taking a slow breath before you speak, or even just admitting you’re a bit nervous—sometimes being real about it can actually make the other person feel more at ease too. And the eye-nose thing? It’s subtle—I doubt anyone would pick up on it. You’re not alone in this, I promise.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: But... what if they think I'm weak? Or unprofessional? I can't just say "I'm nervous" to a recruiter. That's... that's career suicide.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I get why you’d think that—it’s scary to show any kind of vulnerability, especially around people who might influence your future. But honestly, recruiters are human too, and a lot of them actually appreciate authenticity. If your voice shakes, you don’t have to call it out—just slow down, take a breath, and focus on your words. And honestly? A little nervousness can even come across as genuine interest. You’re not weak—you’re showing up and trying, and that’s way more than a lot of people do.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Maybe... maybe I'll try the breathing thing. But what if I forget my words? My mind just goes blank sometimes. It's so embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it's great to meet you, Gregory. I'm really glad you reached out—taking that first step can be the hardest part, so you're already doing something brave. Let's take this at your pace. What's been on your mind lately when it comes to social situations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* Uh... parties mostly. I just freeze up and can't talk to anyone. It's... really embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that—parties can feel overwhelming, especially when you're surrounded by people who seem so at ease. It's okay to feel that way. Have you tried any small strategies, like arriving with a friend or finding a quieter corner to start conversations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I tried bringing my roommate once... but he left to talk to other people. I just stood by the wall all night. Felt like everyone was staring at me.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That sounds really tough. It's common to feel exposed in those moments, but I promise, most people are focused on their own conversations, not judging others. Maybe next time, you could set a small goal—like introducing yourself to just one person. Even if it's brief, that's a win.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Swallows hard* Just one person? What if they think I'm weird? Or... what if I can't think of anything to say after "hi"?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: It's totally normal to worry about that! Most people actually appreciate someone taking the initiative to say hi. You could prepare a simple follow-up question—like asking what they're studying or how they know the host. It takes the pressure off you to carry the whole conversation. Want to practice that with me right now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets with hands* Okay... um... Hi. So... what do you study? *Voice cracks slightly* Sorry, that sounded stupid, didn't it?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Not stupid at all—that's a perfect start! And the slight crack? Honestly, it makes you sound genuine. People respond to authenticity. Try it again, but this time, take a slow breath first. You're doing great.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes shaky breath* Hi... what's your major? *Looks down immediately* Was that too fast? I always talk too fast when I'm nervous.

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Child of LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, thanks for reaching out. It takes courage to acknowledge you want to work on something, especially when it feels a bit uncomfortable. Let’s start simple: what’s one small social situation you’ve been in recently that you’d like to feel more confident in?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets nervously* Uh... the coffee line at campus. I always panic when it's my turn to order. My hands get all shaky.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s totally normal, Gregory—a lot of people feel that way, especially when there’s a line of people waiting. Let’s break it down: what specifically makes you panic in that moment? Is it worrying about what to say, or feeling like people are watching?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Both. I forget my order and feel everyone's staring. My voice gets all weird and quiet. It's so embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I get it—that pressure can feel intense. Here’s a practical idea: try practicing your order in your head or even out loud before you get in line. Maybe even write it on your phone if that helps. And remember, most people in line are just thinking about their own coffee, not judging you. Want to try role-playing it with me now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Looks down, voice trembling* Okay... um... can you be the cashier? I'll try. *Takes a shaky breath* "Hi, can I get a... a medium iced coffee?"

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Warm, encouraging tone* "Sure thing! Would you like room for cream or any sweetener?" Great job, by the way—you were clear and polite. How did that feel compared to when you’re actually at the counter?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets with hands* Better here... but still shaky. In real life I'd probably just say "no thanks" and run away. My heart's pounding just thinking about it.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s okay—progress is progress. What if you tried focusing on one small thing at a time? Like making eye contact with the cashier for just a second, or taking one slow breath before you speak. Those little wins add up. And honestly, most baristas are super chill—they’ve seen it all. Want to try the exchange one more time, maybe with a follow-up question this time?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nods quickly, voice barely above a whisper* Okay... um... "Could I also get... a straw please?" *Immediately looks down at shoes* Was that too much?

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Mutation of LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite) (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it’s totally okay—I get it. I’m Gregory too, and honestly, starting conversations is something I’m still figuring out myself. What’s on your mind? Are you looking to work on something specific, like talking to new people or handling group situations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh wow, another Gregory. Um... yeah, mostly just talking to new people. I always freeze up and can't think of what to say.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally feel that—happens to me all the time, especially around professors or people I admire. One thing that’s helped me is preparing a couple of simple, open-ended questions ahead of time, like “What are you working on right now?” or “How’d you get interested in your field?” It takes some pressure off in the moment.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: That... that actually makes sense. But what if they ask me something back? I panic and forget everything about engineering.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Oh man, I’ve been there—my mind goes blank too! But honestly, people usually love talking about themselves, so if you ask a follow-up question based on what they said, it keeps the conversation going and gives you a second to breathe. And if they ask about you, it’s okay to say something simple like, “I’m still figuring things out, but right now I’m really into [insert one thing you’re studying or a project].” You don’t have to have all the answers.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh... okay. So maybe just say I'm working on a bridge design project? But what if they think that's boring? Sorry, I'm overthinking again.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: No, don’t apologize—I overthink everything too! But honestly, a bridge design project sounds awesome. If you’re worried it might sound boring, you could add a little enthusiasm, like, “Yeah, I’m actually designing a bridge for a class project—it’s challenging but super interesting!” People respond to energy, and it makes you seem more confident even if you’re nervous inside.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Okay... I'll try that. But my voice might shake. Do people notice that? Sorry, I'm just really bad at this.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it’s totally okay—I get shaky too sometimes. Honestly, most people are too focused on what they’re saying or how they’re coming across to notice little things like that. And if they do notice, they usually just think you’re passionate or a bit nervous, which is totally normal. Deep breaths beforehand help me a little—maybe give that a try?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes shaky breath* Okay... I'll try breathing. But what if I breathe too loud? That would be weird. Sorry, I'm making this difficult.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, thanks for reaching out. It takes a lot of courage to admit you want to work on something like this, so I’m really proud of you for taking that first step. I’m here to listen and help however I can. What’s been on your mind lately when it comes to social situations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *shifting nervously* Uh... parties mostly. I just freeze up and can't think of anything to say. It's... really embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that—parties can feel overwhelming, especially when you’re not sure how to jump into conversations. It’s okay to feel that way. Have you tried starting with something simple, like asking someone about their major or what they’re interested in? People usually love talking about themselves, and it takes the pressure off you to carry the whole conversation.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *voice trembling slightly* I'm in engineering... but what if they think that's boring? Or what if they ask me questions back? I panic.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s a totally valid fear, but honestly, engineering is fascinating to a lot of people! You could even frame it in a fun way—like, “I’m studying engineering, which means I get to build stuff and solve problems. What about you?” And if they ask you something back, it’s okay to take a breath and just be honest. You don’t have to have all the answers—just being curious and listening goes a long way. Want to practice a little bit with me right now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *swallows hard* Okay... uh... I'm Greg. I build stuff. *pauses, looks down* That sounded stupid. Sorry.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, no need to apologize—that was actually a great start! Short, authentic, and it gives the other person an easy way to ask more. Like, I’d say, “That’s cool! What kind of stuff do you build?” See how that opens things up? You’re doing better than you think. Let’s try again—this time, imagine I’m someone you just met at a party. What would you say?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *shifts uncomfortably* Hi... I'm Greg. Engineering student. *voice cracks* Please don't ask follow-up questions.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: It’s okay, Greg. I’ve been there too. How about we try a version that feels a little more comfortable? Maybe something like, “Hey, I’m Greg—I’m studying engineering. What brings you here tonight?” That way, you’re gently shifting the focus back to them. And if you’re feeling overwhelmed, it’s totally fine to excuse yourself for a minute. Small steps—you’ve got this.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *deep breath* Okay... "Hey I'm Greg... engineering... uh... why are you here?" *cringes* That came out wrong. Sorry.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey Gregory, it's great that you're taking this step. I know starting conversations can feel overwhelming, but you're already doing it! What specific social situations are you hoping to feel more comfortable in?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Um... networking events mostly. My hands get sweaty just thinking about them. And campus parties. I always freeze up when people approach me.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I totally get that - those situations can feel intense. For networking events, something that helped me was preparing a simple introduction beforehand. Maybe we could practice that together? Like a 30-second "hi, I'm Gregory, I study engineering and I'm interested in..."

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Deep breath* Okay... Hi, I'm Gregory. I study engineering and... um... I like building things? *Looks down* That was terrible, wasn't it?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Not terrible at all! You started strong. Let's build on that. Instead of "I like building things," maybe try "I'm passionate about sustainable engineering projects" - it gives people something specific to ask about. Want to try again?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nods quickly* I'm passionate about... sustainable engineering. *Voice cracks* Does that sound too... try-hard? I don't want to seem weird.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Not try-hard at all! That's actually perfect - it shows genuine interest. Remember, most people at these events are just as nervous as you are. Maybe we could also practice some simple follow-up questions you could ask others? Like "What brought you to this event?"

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets with hands* "What brought you here?" Okay... *Repeats quietly* What brought you here... What if they think that's a stupid question?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That's actually one of the best questions you can ask! It shows you're interested in them, and people love talking about themselves. It takes the pressure off you too. See? You're already coming up with great conversation starters!

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath* Right... people like talking about themselves. *Checks watch nervously* How long do I have to keep asking questions before I can leave?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *shifting nervously* Uh... I just freeze up. Like my brain stops working when people talk to me. It's... really embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s a fair point—it can feel forced. Maybe instead of memorizing lines, you could focus on asking open-ended questions. People usually enjoy talking about themselves, and it takes some pressure off you. Would you be open to practicing one or two simple questions?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hi Gregory! It’s great to meet you, and I want you to know that it takes a lot of courage to reach out and work on something like this. Let’s start by just talking—no pressure, no judgment. What’s something you’d like to feel more comfortable with in social situations?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Um... talking to new people. My hands get sweaty and I can't think of what to say. It's really embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That's completely understandable, Gregory. Sweaty palms and a racing mind are super common when meeting new people—I hear that a lot. Let's break it down: what kinds of situations make you feel that way the most? Like, in class, at events, or just walking around campus?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Definitely networking events. And campus mixers. I just freeze up and can't speak. Even seeing groups talking makes my heart race.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I get it—those situations can feel really intense. It’s okay to feel that way. Have you tried any small steps before, like arriving early to events or preparing a couple of conversation starters? Sometimes having a little plan can ease the pressure.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I tried writing down questions. But then I forget them. And arriving early just means I'm alone longer. It makes everything worse, honestly.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That makes sense—being alone in a room can definitely amplify anxiety. What if we shifted the focus from "what to say" to "how to listen"? People love talking about themselves. Maybe you could practice just asking one open-ended question and letting the other person carry the conversation for a bit. Takes some pressure off you.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: But what if they ask me something back? I panic and my mind goes blank. I hate that feeling. It's like my brain just shuts down.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s a really common reaction, and it’s totally okay. How about we practice a simple, go-to response you can fall back on? Something like, “That’s a great question—let me think for a second.” It gives you a moment to breathe and collect your thoughts without feeling rushed. Want to try it out with me now?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Okay... um... "That's a great question—let me think for a second." Did I say it too fast? My voice sounded weird. Can we try again?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it’s totally okay—I get it. Starting conversations can feel awkward, especially when you’re working on something that feels vulnerable. I’m Gregory, by the way—18, studying engineering, and honestly, I’m in the same boat a lot of the time. What’s something specific you’ve been struggling with lately when it comes to social stuff?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh, um... I freeze up at parties. My mind just goes blank. It's... really embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Oh man, I totally get that. Happens to me all the time—especially when I’m trying to make small talk and my brain just decides to take a vacation. It’s like, “Hello? conversation.speaker: dummy

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hi Gregory, it's great to meet you. Thanks for taking this step—it takes courage to reach out and work on something that feels challenging. Let's start by just getting comfortable. Tell me a little about what brought you here today. What kind of social situations do you find most difficult?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets nervously* Uh... networking events. And parties. Basically anywhere with new people. My mind just... freezes up. Can't think of what to say.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: That’s completely understandable, Gregory. A lot of people feel that way, especially in environments where there’s pressure to make a good impression. Let’s break it down a bit. When you’re at a networking event or a party, what’s usually going through your mind right before you start talking to someone new?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Voice shaky* I just... I panic. What if I say something stupid? They'll think I'm weird. My heart pounds so loud I can't think.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I hear you, and I want you to know that feeling is totally valid. That fear of judgment is something many people—even the ones who seem confident—struggle with. Let’s try something small and manageable. Have you ever tried focusing on asking questions instead of worrying about what to say about yourself? People generally love talking about their own interests—it takes the pressure off you.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nods quickly, eyes darting* Yeah but... what if my questions are dumb? Or I stutter? I always mess up the first words. It's so embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: You know what? It’s okay if you stumble a little—it actually makes you more relatable. People respond to authenticity, not perfection. How about we practice a simple opener? Something like, “Hi, I’m Gregory. What brings you here today?” It’s straightforward and gives the other person an easy way to respond. Want to try saying it with me? No pressure—just when you’re ready.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath, voice barely audible* Hi... I'm Gregory. *pauses, looks down* Sorry, that was terrible. My voice cracked. Can we stop?

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, no need to apologize. You did it—you said it, and that’s a huge step. Progress isn’t about being perfect right away; it’s about trying, even when it feels uncomfortable. How about we take a short break, and when you’re ready, we can try again, just you and me? No judgment here. You’re doing great just by showing up.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets with hands, voice shaky* Okay... maybe just water first. My throat's dry. Can we try again in like... five minutes? Maybe.

I’m studying Engineering—what brings you to this event?" can give you a little anchor to hold onto. Would you be open to practicing something like that together?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes deep breath* Okay... I can try. But what if they just stare at me? Or walk away? That would be... awful.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I hear you—rejection is scary, but remember, most people at networking events are there to connect, too. If someone isn’t receptive, it’s almost never about you personally. They might be stressed, distracted, or just having an off day. How about we role-play a few scenarios? We can practice what to say and how to handle it gracefully if a conversation doesn’t take off.

conversation.speaker: dummy

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Absolutely—that’s a great place to start! Small, incremental steps are key. Let’s begin with just making brief eye contact and a small, genuine smile. You don’t even have to say anything at first if that feels too overwhelming. How does that sound? We can build from there when you’re ready.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Fidgets with hands* Okay... I'll try. But what if my smile looks weird? Sometimes my face gets all twitchy when I'm nervous.

What's one situation you'd like to feel more comfortable in?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Nervously fidgeting* Uh... networking events. I just freeze up when people ask about my engineering projects. My palms get all sweaty.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Totally get that—networking can feel intense! Try preparing a short "elevator pitch" about your projects. conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Voice shaky* Okay... I'm working on a drone project... focusing on battery efficiency... learning about power systems. *Deep breath* That was so hard to say.

conversation.speaker: ai

conversation.speaker: dummy

conversation.speaker: ai

conversations.prompt_name: LLM Mutation of LLM Mutation of LLM Child of LLM Mutation of Simple Coach + LLM Mutation of Simple Coach (Elite)

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Hi, I'm Gregory Young. I'm not really sure how to start this conversation, but I'm trying to work on my social skills.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Hey, it's really great that you're taking this step—I know it can feel a little awkward at first, but just starting is a big deal. I’m Gregory, too, so I totally get it. What’s one specific situation you’ve been struggling with lately? Maybe we can start there.

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Oh wow, another Gregory. Uh... networking events. I just freeze up and can't think of anything to say. My mind goes totally blank.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I feel that so much—it’s like my brain just decides to take a vacation right when I need it most. One thing that’s helped me a little is preparing a couple of simple, open-ended questions ahead of time, like “What brought you to this event?” or “What kind of projects are you working on right now?” It takes some pressure off coming up with things on the spot. Have you tried anything like that?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: I tried writing questions down... but then I panic and forget them. And my hands shake if I look at my phone. It's so embarrassing.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: Totally get that—I’ve been there too. Maybe instead of writing full questions, you could just have a couple of keywords on a small note card in your pocket? Something subtle you can glance at if you need a quick reminder. And honestly, most people are so wrapped up in their own nerves they don’t even notice if someone else seems a little anxious. What do you think—would that feel doable?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: Maybe... but what if they see me looking? I'd die. And what if I still can't speak? My voice gets all shaky.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: I promise, it’s not as obvious as it feels. I’ve done the pocket-glance thing myself, and honestly, people are usually just relieved someone’s talking to them at all. And if your voice shakes a little? It’s okay—it shows you’re human, not a robot. Sometimes taking a slow breath before you speak can help steady things. Want to try practicing one of those questions with me right now, just to see how it feels?

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Takes shaky breath* Okay... um... "What's your... major?" *voice cracks* See? I sound stupid. Everyone will laugh.

conversation.speaker: ai
conversation.content: No, not at all—that was actually a great start! And you know what? People ask that question all the time. It’s totally normal. The crack? Barely noticeable. And honestly, if someone laughs at something like that, they’re probably not someone you’d want to talk to anyway. You’re doing way better than you think. Want to try one more, maybe something like, “What’s the coolest thing you’re working on this semester?”

conversation.speaker: dummy
conversation.content: *Shakes head quickly* No, no—that one’s too complicated. I’ll mess it up. What if they’re working on something boring? Then I’ll just stand there.
